title: Social conformity
prayerSummary: Give thanks for Japanese believers who know that, through Jesus, God accepts them as they are.
Pray for Japanese people who are facing severe effects of stress to put their faith in Christ and receive his grace.
Pray that Japanese Christians would have wisdom from God to respond to social pressures.
textBody:
“I could never become a Christian; no one in my family has ever been one. I would betray them if I did.”
“My boss calls at 6 a.m. on my day off to tell me to come to work, so I have to go.”
“I’ve never spoken about Jesus at work because I don’t want to break the harmony.”
“I can’t pray at church because I can’t pray like other people.”

Pressure—to conform, to not make mistakes, to not admit weaknesses, to work beyond their limits—is often felt deeply by Japanese people. Many hide their true selves and are sensitive to how they are being viewed by others. When the daily stresses add up, the effects can be dire: mental health concerns, alcoholism, estranged families, and even suicide.

In a country where Christians are a tiny minority, pressure to conform can be felt as pressure not to become a Christian. For believers, conformity can be felt as pressure to keep their faith private and their struggles hidden.
In Christ, we find grace, acceptance, and rest, but in a pressurized society, those truths can be hard to believe and even harder to live out.

photos.title: Students in uniform on a school trip in Nagasaki.

Students in uniform in Yokohama. Most middle schools and high schools have strict policies regarding clothing and appearance. In recent years, some policies such as designated underwear color, hairstyles, and dyeing naturally brown hair black have come under question.

Students interacting with each other on a school trip in Yokohama. The pressures of group dynamics are felt from a young age. According to a 2021 report by the Cabinet Office, the top three challenges for youth in school were bullying, group participation, and relationships with friends.

Young women in kimono at their university graduation. Young adults often feel more freedom of self-expression in university, but quickly come up against strong societal expectations when looking for employment.
Young women waiting in line to enter a trendy fashion shop in Tokyo. In a society that favors conformity, fashion can be a means of self-expression, particularly among young adults.

A woman with a group of children eating lunch. Women face traditional expectations to be their children's primary caregiver, as well as more recent expectations to be active in Japan's shrinking workforce.

A woman in the middle of her workday. Women in the workplace are often confronted with gender-based limitations. The global 'Me Too' movement inspired the viral hashtag 'KuToo' in 2019, which Japanese women used to speak out against company policies forcing them to wear high heels to work and other gender-based disparities.
Men face their own pressures in the workplace, particularly to work long hours, maintain good relationships with co-workers and superiors, and be their family's primary breadwinner.
Nagoya station during the evening rush hour.
A group of men having a quick drink after work. Working people often face pressure to attend social gatherings with their co-workers.
Lines of people waiting for the train at Akihabara station in Tokyo. There are many unspoken rules regarding train etiquette, which local people take care to follow.
People on a crowded train platform in Tokyo. Life in big cities can feel pressurized with little room for personal space.
The train platform is covered with many different instructions. Here, people are following instructions to line up for the train to Haneda airport.
Arrows indicate how people should use the stairs. These instructions help manage the flow of people during busy times.
A poster showing how to use the escalator. However, in many cities, different unspoken rules trump these guidelines.
Unspoken rules about the escalator in some cities include standing to the left and walking on the right.
A row of bicycles parked next to a 'No Bicycles Parking' sign. Sometimes social conformity can mean following the majority instead of following instructions.
Instructions to keep right on the stairs, next to a notice about not being a nuisance. Not being a nuisance to others is a key motivation for following social rules and expectations in Japan.
